alert.note: Alert for Richland (North Dakota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks (Northeastern North Dakota and Northwestern Minnesota)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued December 26 at 10:48PM CST until December 30 at 4:00PM CST by NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Minnesota...North Dakota... Red River of the North at Wahpeton affecting Wilkin and Richland Counties. ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Minnesota...North Dakota... Red River of the North at Fargo affecting Clay and Cass Counties. Wild Rice River (ND) near Abercrombie affecting Richland County. .Recent rainfall due to a large area of low pressure with accompanying above normal seasonal temperatures resulted in up to around 2 inches of liquid precipitation falling in the southern Red River Basin. The rain fell on mostly frozen ground allowing the water to run off into into the mainstem Red River. Addition flows moving north on the Bois de Sioux near Lake Traverse are also contributing to the river rises. Therefore, the forecast is for Wahpeton, Fargo and Abercrombie to reach minor flood stage. For the Red River...including Wahpeton, Fargo...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Wild Rice River (ND)...including Abercrombie...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT FROM WEDNESDAY EVENING TO SATURDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Red River of the North at Wahpeton. * WHEN...From Wednesday evening to Saturday afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 11.6 feet, Otter Tail River water starts to flow into the Breckenridge Diversion. Water on Main Street (Breckenridge). * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:30 PM CST Tuesday the stage was 8.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 10.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late tomorrow evening to a crest of 11.6 feet early Thursday afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage late Friday morning. - Flood stage is 11.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued late Wednesday night at 500 AM CST.
